trustfund: TF021845-REFORMS IN THE BOLIVIAN PENSION SYSTEM,TF039090-BOLIVIA - JUDICIAL REFORM,TF037530-BOLIVIA - JUDICIAL REFORM,TF037529-BOLIVIA - JUDICIAL REFORM,TF036909-BOLIVIA - JUDICIAL REFORM PROJECT,TF036908-PERU - JUDICIAL REFORM PROJECT,TF036818-DOMINICAN REPUBLIC - JUDICIAL REFORM,TF035417-BOLIVIA - JUDICIAL REFORM,TF035395-BOLIVIA - JUDICIAL REFORM PROJECT,TF034114-PERU - JUDICIAL REFORM PROJECT,TF033933-BOLIVIA - JUDICIAL REFORM PROJECT,TF033795-BOLIVIA - JUDICIAL REFORM

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, although its sustainability is unlikely,
            because despite renewed commitments by the Government, the
            international community, and the people of Bolivia to pursue
            judicial reforms, the political environment was not
            congenial to the Government, in the absence of a solid
            majority required in the national parliament for approving
            new laws, or amending the existing laws; thus, the Bank
            financing is being reconsidered. Regardless of satisfactory
            outcomes, lessons suggest a balanced approach between the
            complexity of the sector, and the variety of stakeholders,
            because the broad scope of the project, led to the inclusion
            of too many components, whereas priority implementation
            strategies should have been identified, and agreed upon
            early on. Thus, on designing a judicial reform project, the
            use of sociopolitical institutional assessments should be a
            powerful tool for assessing alternative reform options, and
            include the appropriate implementation strategies.
            Furthermore, coordination has political dimensions that do
            not respond well to technical, or managerial solutions, nor
            to weak institutional capacity, thus the persistent lack of
            committed coordination between the Judiciary, and the
            Ministry of Justice hindered stronger results, and perhaps
            prevented flexible judicial reform strategies, critical for
            a project to survive recurrent crisis in the sector.
